message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only etoposide inhibits supercoil relaxation, which leads to DNA damage and apoptosis of cancer cells. Alkylation and crosslinking of DNA are seen with other chemotherapeutic agents, and stabilization of microtubules is the mechanism of action for drugs like paclitaxel.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Etoposide inhibits supercoil relaxation, which prevents DNA replication and ultimately leads to cell death. This mechanism helps to treat cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Etoposide is an inhibitor of topoisomerase II, which is involved in supercoil relaxation of DNA. Inhibition of this enzyme leads to DNA damage and cancer cell death. Therefore, the beneficial effect of this drug in treating cancer is most likely due to inhibition of supercoil relaxation. Myelosuppression is a common side effect of chemotherapy drugs due to their impact on rapidly dividing cells, including bone marrow cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Etoposide functions by inhibiting topoisomerase II, thereby preventing DNA unwinding and supercoil relaxation, ultimately leading to cell death. This mechanism is described in option (C). Options (A) and (B) involve damaging DNA directly, while (D) involves stabilizing microtubules and is not directly related to the mechanism of etoposide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Etoposide targets topoisomerase II, an enzyme responsible for unwinding and relaxing DNA, and inhibits its ability to relax supercoils. By preventing supercoil relaxation, the drug impedes normal DNA replication and transcription, ultimately leading to cancer cell death.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Etoposide inhibits supercoil relaxation, which prevents DNA replication in cancer cells and ultimately leads to cell death. This is the mechanism responsible for its therapeutic effect in treating cancer. Myelosuppression, which increases the risk of infection, is a common side effect of etoposide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Etoposide primarily works by inhibiting supercoil relaxation, leading to DNA damage and ultimately apoptosis of cancer cells. Myelosuppression is a common side effect of this drug but is not related to its mechanism of action. Alkylation and crosslinking of DNA and stabilization of microtubules are mechanisms of action for other chemotherapeutic drugs such as cisplatin and paclitaxel, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Etoposide works by inhibiting supercoil relaxation, which leads to DNA damage and cell death. This mechanism targets rapidly dividing cells like cancer cells. The other options are mechanisms of action for other chemotherapeutic agents, but not for etoposide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Etoposide inhibits supercoil relaxation, ultimately leading to DNA damage and cell death. This effect on DNA is beneficial in treating cancer. Alkylation of DNA and crosslinking of DNA are mechanisms of action of other chemotherapeutic agents, while stabilization of microtubules is a mechanism of action of drugs such as paclitaxel.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only etoposide inhibits supercoil relaxation by targeting topoisomerase II. This inhibition leads to double-stranded DNA breakage and cell death.
